header: 6.5 Safe misfire treatment and management process

title: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
file_name: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench.txt
document: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
header: 6.5.1 Re-firing shall be done provided there would be sufficient time to fire within day time

title: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
file_name: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench.txt
document: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
header: 6.5.2 At no time shall anyone approach an area containing a total misfire (total initiation failure) until: i) If firing electrically, firing cables have been disconnected from the source of electricity and short circuited and 10 minutes have elapsed. ii) Where safety fuse is used, until 30 minutes have lapsed since the fuse was lit iii) Where nonelectric initiation is used, 10 minutes must be allowed to pass before re-entry permitted to the blasting site

title: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
file_name: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench.txt
document: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
header: 6.5.2 At no time shall anyone approach an area containing a total misfire (total initiation failure) until: i) If firing electrically, firing cables have been disconnected from the source of electricity and short circuited and 10 minutes have elapsed. ii) Where safety fuse is used, until 30 minutes have lapsed since the fuse was lit iii) Where nonelectric initiation is used, 10 minutes must be allowed to pass before re-entry permitted to the blasting site

title: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
file_name: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench.txt
document: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
header: 6.5.3 If it is not possible to re-fire the affected area, the blast controller shall ensure that the blast guards remain in position until the Blasting Supervisor has effectively barred off access to the affected area

title: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
file_name: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench.txt
document: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
header: 6.5.4 Warning signs, flags and cones shall be placed to delineate the area no less than 6 metres from the nearest unfired blasthole

title: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
file_name: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench.txt
document: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
header: 6.5.5 If the misfire is to remain overnight a guard shall also be placed at the charged area

title: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
file_name: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench.txt
document: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
header: 6.5.6 Any unfired surface accessories shall be removed from the area and taken to the portable magazine for later destruction

title: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
file_name: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench.txt
document: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
header: 6.5.7 At no time shall it be permitted to reuse surface blasting accessories which have been involved in a misfire

title: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
file_name: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench.txt
document: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
header: 6.5.8 This occurrence shall be recorded in the log book as soon as practical by the Blasting Supervisor

title: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
file_name: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench.txt
document: Treatment of misfires on a surface mine or bench
header: 6.5.9 The entry shall describe the nature of the misfire and the specific location in the pit

header: 6.4 Instructions Before doing any work at the magazines a pre-task risk assessment shall be done No contraband shall be brought into the magazines Magazine maintenance and inspections shall be done in conjunction with the client (HCCL) who is the custodian of the explosives magazines

title: Storage of explosives
header: 6.5.1 During weekly inspections of the magazines, the Magazine Master shall check for adequate signage and fencing outside the magazines, as well as good ventilation, dryness and termites inside the magazines

title: Storage of explosives
header: 6.5.2 A fire guard shall be maintained around the fencing, both inside and outside the fence

title: Storage of explosives
header: 6.5.3 The Magazine Master shall ensure that water drains away from the magazines

title: Storage of explosives
header: 6.5.4 The Magazine Master shall ensure that the lightning conductor is tested once every year as per the requirements of the Explosives Regulations

title: Storage of explosives
header: 6.5.5 The Magazine Master shall ensure that ventilation in the magazines is adequate

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 1 Issue Date July 2018 PAGE_START:2 Uncontrolled Copy. This document is controlled only in electronic format or when stamped "Controlled Document". Otherwise, it is valid as a record only.

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 4.0 DEFINITIONS & ABBREVIATIONS SWP - Safe Working Practice MIN - Mining DB - Drill & Blast

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.1 PPE Required Reflective clothing, safety shoes/gum boots, hard hat, goggles, ear plugs, dust masks, gloves

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.2 Tools & equipment Rig, shovels, survey equipment, lighting plant, cone markers

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.3 Equipment care and maintenance Pre-start checks shall always be done and recorded on the prescribed checklist before using equipment

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 1 Issue Date July 2018 PAGE_START:3 Uncontrolled Copy. This document is controlled only in electronic format or when stamped "Controlled Document". Otherwise, it is valid as a record only.

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.4 Instructions Before recovering the lost drill string a pre-task risk assessment shall be done The Drilling and Blasting Engineer shall be consulted before a decision is made to abandon a stuck drill string

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.5 Safe recovery of stuck drill string

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.5.1 The Rig Operator and Rig Assistant shall ensure that only one person at a time communicates with the Operator during the recovery process, except in case of emergency

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.5.2 Where it is possible to uncouple the rotary head from the stuck pipe(s) below, the Drill Rig Operator shall break off the pipe(s) and then with the Rig Assistant guiding, gradually elevate the machine while keeping it level from time to time until the deck clears the protruding pipe from below

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.5.3 The Drill Rig Operator shall gradually fold the mast to its resting position and the rig shall be tracked away from the pipe

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.5.4 The Rig Assistant shall stand at least 5m clear of the rig to keep away from any loose rig components that may accidentally fall from mast

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.5.5 Where it is not possible to break off the pipe(s) the Drilling Supervisor shall call for Boilermakers to cut the drill pipe below the deck

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.5.6 Before cutting a pre-task risk assessment shall be done, including making sure that there is no oil spillage or any other flammable materials around the area to be cut with an oxy-acetylene plant

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.5.7 A serviceable fire extinguisher shall always be available before cutting begins

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.5.8 The rod shall be cut less than 0.5m from above the ground and the rotary head slightly raised inorder to clear contact with the protruding drill pipe

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.5.9 The mast shall be gradually folded and the rig tracked away from the rod

title: Recovery of lost drill string
header: 6.5.10 The remaining piece of rod on machine shall be broken off, unscrewed and

header: 5.0 LEGAL REQUIREMENTS Mining (Management and Safety) Regulations, S.I. 109 of 1990, Section 31, Safety in working places Mining (Management and Safety) Regulations, SI109 of 1990, Section 292, Safety precautions to be observed by all persons Explosives Regulations, S.I. 72 of 1989, Section 57, Approaching misfired charges Explosives Regulations, S.I. 72 of 1989, Section 60, Blasting schedule and time lapse after blasting Parks and Wild Life Act, Chapter 20:14, Revised Edition 1996, Section 63, Report of killing of animals or injury of animals other than dangerous animals Parks and Wild Life Act, Chapter 20:14, Revised Edition 1996, Section 64, Report of injury of dangerous animals

header: 5.0 LEGAL REQUIREMENTS Mining (Management and Safety) Regulations, S.I. 109 of 1990, Section 31, Safety in working places Mining (Management and Safety) Regulations, SI109 of 1990, Section 292, Safety precautions to be observed by all persons Explosives Regulations, S.I. 72 of 1989, Section 57, Approaching misfired charges Explosives Regulations, S.I. 72 of 1989, Section 60, Blasting schedule and time lapse after blasting Parks and Wild Life Act, Chapter 20:14, Revised Edition 1996, Section 63, Report of killing of animals or injury of animals other than dangerous animals Parks and Wild Life Act, Chapter 20:14, Revised Edition 1996, Section 64, Report of injury of dangerous animals

title: Re-Entry on a surface mine
header: 6.1 PPE Required Reflective clothing, safety shoes/gum boots, hard hat, goggles, dust masks

title: Re-Entry on a surface mine
header: 6.2 Tools & equipment to use Cone markers, barrier tape, empty drums, two-way radio set, aluminium or copper knife, canvas bag, gas tester, drager pump, gas detector tubes.

title: Re-Entry on a surface mine
header: 3 Issue Date July 2018 PAGE_START:3 Uncontrolled Copy. This document is controlled only in electronic format or when stamped "Controlled Document". Otherwise, it is valid as a record only.

title: Re-Entry on a surface mine
header: 6.4 Instruction The pre-task risk assessment for re-entry shall be done before blasting, incorporating the blasting process Dust shall be allowed to clear before re-entry

title: Re-Entry on a surface mine
header: 6.5.1 After the dust and fumes have cleared but in not less than 5 minutes after a successful blast the Blasting Controller shall proceed for re-entry

title: Re-Entry on a surface mine
header: 6.5.2 If upon initiation, the blast fails to go off i.e. misfires, the siren long ring shall be discontinued and a waiting period of 10 minutes allowed before the misfire can be rectified

title: Re-Entry on a surface mine
header: 6.5.3 After rectifying the misfire the long ring shall be re-sounded and the blast retaken while the siren is ringing and discontinued soon after the bang

title: Re-Entry on a surface mine
header: 6.5.4 The re-entry team shall proceed with caution, taking into consideration any ground carvings and fly rock that could damage vehicle tyres

title: Re-Entry on a surface mine
header: 6.5.5 Where the blast has taken place in a confined area with no free air circulation the team shall test for noxious gases in the general body of air including carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), nitrous fumes (NxOy) and methane (CH4)

title: Re-Entry on a surface mine
header: 6.5.6 Permissible quantities for the gases shall be taken as CO=100ppm, CO2=5000ppm, NxOy=5ppm, CH4=1.25%, hydrogen sulphide (H2S)=20ppm

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.1 PPE Required Reflective clothing, safety shoes/gum boots, hard hat, goggles, ear plugs, dust masks, gloves

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.2 Tools & equipment to use Drill rig, shovels, measuring tape, lighting plant, copper hammer, empty sacks, white wash, cone markers, barrier tape, empty drums

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.4 Instructions A pre-task risk assessment shall always be done before drilling commences There shall be no edge drilling during night shift The rig assistant shall always guide the rig operator when manoeuvring

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.5.1 The Rig Operator shall use the side glass and/or panel to check for engine coolant level and/or coolant temperature

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.5.2 Where the Rig Operator is expected to open the radiator cap, 45mins shall be allowed from the time the machine was switched off, before attempting to open the radiator cap to check for coolant. The operator shall still exercise extreme caution when opening the coolant cap

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.5.3 The jacks shall be levelled on solid ground while the mast is still down

title: Bench Drilling
header: 1 Issue Date July 2018 PAGE_START:4 Uncontrolled Copy. This document is controlled only in electronic format or when stamped "Controlled Document". Otherwise, it is valid as a record only.

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.5.4 The operator shall check the ground engagement tools for wear before drilling commences

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.5.5 All persons close to the rig shall put on hard hat, goggles, dust masks and ear plugs always during drilling operations

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.5.6 The operator shall make sure that dust suppression and lubrication systems are functional and he shall ensure that the machine always has water for dust suppression.

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.5.7 When drilling close to an edge the rig shall always be perpendicular to the edge and the rear jacks shall be at least 2m away from the edge and on consolidated ground

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.5.8 When tracking the rig on rugged ground the assistant and operator shall exercise extreme caution to ensure that the rig does not fall over

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.5.9 When manoeuvring and drilling on sloppy ground, the operator shall always make sure that the cab is on the uphill side

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.5.10 The assistant shall wear gloves when assisting on the rig

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.5.11 On approach of an electrical storm the operator shall discontinue drilling,

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.5.12 All the holes shall be marked by Survey or as indicated by the Drilling

title: Bench Drilling
header: 6.5.13 The assistant and operator shall make sure that they drill only on marked

title: Bush clearing and bench preparatiton
header: 6.1 PPE Required Reflective clothing, safety shoes/gum boots, hard hat, goggles, dust masks, gloves

title: Bush clearing and bench preparatiton
header: 6.2 Tools & equipment to use Dozer, excavator, red and green flags, gas tester, dragger pump, gas detector tubes

title: Bush clearing and bench preparatiton
header: 6.4 Instructions Before bush clearing and bench preparation a pre-task risk assessment shall always be done Bush clearing shall only be done during day light For any confined workplace where there is no free circulation of air, the drill and blast supervisor or an assigned holder of a valid blasting licence shall test for noxious gases including carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), nitrous fumes (NxOy) and methane (CH4) in the general body of air Where there is stagnant water and rotting timber hydrogen sulphide (H2S) shall also be tested for Permissible quantities for the gases shall be taken as CO=100ppm, CO2=5000ppm, NxOy=5ppm, CH4=1.25%, H2S=20ppm If gases are detected the working area shall be made safe in accordance with the regulations and re-entry done to the satisfactory of the regulations before work commences or continue

title: Bush clearing and bench preparatiton

title: Bush clearing and bench preparatiton
header: 6.5 Safe bush clearing and bench preparation

title: Bush clearing and bench preparatiton
header: 6.5.1 The Drilling Supervisor shall liaise with the Drill & Blast Engineer and Surveyor to ascertain the extent of area to be bush cleared

title: Bush clearing and bench preparatiton
header: 6.5.2 The Drilling Supervisor shall then discuss with the dozer operator and the spotter the direction and extent of bush clearing

title: Bush clearing and bench preparatiton
header: 6.5.3 The 3 shall carry out a pre-task risk assessment on a prescribed form

title: Bush clearing and bench preparatiton
header: 6.5.4 The Drilling Supervisor shall ensure that the dozer operator has a functional two way radio communication system

title: Bush clearing and bench preparatiton
header: 6.5.5 The dozer operator shall conduct a thorough pre-start check of the machine as well as the dozer belly plate is secured before commencing operations by jacking the machine up and physically inspecting underneath

title: Bush clearing and bench preparatiton
header: 6.5.6 The spotter shall always be alert and watchful for snakes and wild animals and to never position himself in uncleared bush

title: Bush clearing and bench preparatiton
header: 6.5.7 If the dozer is to push material over an edge an inspection shall first be done on the lower side (as part of the pre-task risk assessment) of the edge to ensure that no persons or equipment are exposed to danger

header: 6.4 Instructions A pre-task risk assessment shall always be done before work commences Detonating cord for destruction shall be cut into small lengths of 2m or less and embedded into the bulky explosive charging new holes Detonators shall be bunched into small quantities, at most 5, and embedded into the bulky explosive and always avoid crackling of detonators No contraband shall be allowed into the explosives destruction area Bulky explosive for destruction shall be added to charged holes in small quantities at most 5kg/hole for detonation The destruction area shall be demarcated, delineated and red flags erected Explosives shall never be put into a fire that is already burning If large quantities of explosives or detonators are required to be destroyed, then the explosive's supplier shall be consulted to eliminate any doubts or concerns pertaining to the proposed disposal methods
